subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit Testing Code That Has System.exit(n);
msgSnippet: ... Yes.  Unfortunate. I m hoping future languages won t even have such a construct and will, instead, prefer something a bit more structured such as throw
messageBody:
On 9/10/06, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...> wrote:
>
> Seems like the security manager has that issue with the return code
> though, doesn't it?


Yes. Unfortunate.

I'm hoping future languages won't even have such a construct and will,
instead, prefer something a bit more structured such as "throw new
ApplicationMustExitError(int n)" instead.

Although exiting is not necessarily an error nor an exception, so I'm not
quite sure this is correct either... Interesting problem.

Back to the original problem, the only way I can think of is to sit down and
think about what the return code really means: it sets a variable on the
shell.

So maybe you would fork a JVM that runs the code under test and then inspect
the environment of the shell that was created and check the return value.

Yes, it's interesting to think about what to do when the code can't be
> changed... a fun design challenge, but I'm glad that most of the time
> the code can be changed and it's the right thing to do.
>

Agreed.

--
